text: the joys of Olympic victory have seemed
to turn to ashes the thousand
disappointments of defeat have been
dwarfed by a nightmare in Munich the
1972 Olympic Games in Munich turned from
an international celebration into a
tragedy during the second week of the
event members of the Palestinian
terrorist group Black September ambushed
11 Israeli athletes and held them
hostage in the Olympic Village their
demands included the release of more
than 230 prisoners from Israeli jails it
was a reminder that the Olympics are not
just an athletic stage but a political
one Germany wanted to show the world how
the country had changed since the end of
World War two and the 1936 Olympic Games
which served as a giant propaganda event
for Hitler's Third Reich but when
athletic events were suspended in 1972
the standoff between police and
terrorists was broadcast live across the
world that's a gun all right it ended in
a shootout in the middle of the night on
an airfield outside Munich eleven
Israelis five Palestinians and one
German police officer died before the
game's continued the tragic events cast
a shadow over all the athletic
achievements including mark Spitz's
record seven gold medals now in the
lead-up to the Olympic Games in Sochi
the Russian police and military have
stepped up their fight against militant
groups security is tight as the
government seems determined to present a
peaceful and happy Russia to the world
that was the goal when Moscow hosted the
Olympics in 1980 sport thou art peace
the official film of the games which
we're watching here was resolutely true
it included great cinematography and
devoted lavish attention to Misha the
bear
but it didn't spend a lot of time on the
fact that more than 50 nations boycotted
those Olympic Games over the Soviet war
in Afghanistan the United States
champion that protest and even hosted a
competing Liberty Bell Classic in
Philadelphia in Moscow Russian gymnast
Aleksandr did chaton won a record eight
Olympic medals but again those games are
remembered more for the boycott than for
any athletic achievement this year it's
President Obama who was taking a
political stand at the Olympics he will
not attend the Games in Sochi but is
sending a delegation it includes openly
gay athletes like former figure skating
gold medalist Brian Boitano the question
now is whether these Olympics will be
remembered for events on the athletic
stage or the political one
